reviewText: Emma Thompson's screenplay is superb!  The story retains its charm and is easy to follow, with never a dull moment.  I would recommend this version to anyone who doesn't usually have the patience for period films!

This is one of my all time favorite movies, it is most certainly a *classic*.  The story of the Daschwood sisters' troubles are told so sweetly- the sisters love each other so much and want each to be happy.  It is funny, too, Mrs. Jennings and Charlotte lighten up any person's day  yet they also make you frustrated for Marianne and Elinor. The scenery and  music in this film are lovely... they portray the spirit of the scene you  are watching.  This movie was what made me a Jane Austen fan. Immediately  after watching S&S I read it and fell in love with Jane Austen. I think  everyone should watch this movie, you will be touched!

Emma Thompson again gives a great performance as a pre-Victorian woman of great common sense.  Kate Winslet portrays her sister, who allows her heart rule her life.  The life situations that play out for these two ladies  provide humor, sorrow, and a lesson in life in their time.
Perfect tearjerker.
One of my all time favorite movies!
Favorite book and movie! Emma Thompson did a wonderful job bringing the story to life.  Varies a bit from the book, but the whole story is there.  Great cast too!
good
Can't say enough about the music, screenplay and direction in this film. Love Alan Rickman's beautiful speaking voice.

Middle-aged Emma Thompson is totally miscast as 19 year old Elinor.  I thought Thompson was Elinor's mother at the beginning as the character in the book is only 40. Emma Thompson is a wonderful actress but she would have been more suited to play Elinor's mother or at best, Elinor's older and matronly sister-in-law, Fanny. Furthermore, important characters and subplots are changed or totally eliminated. Consequently, the conclusion of the movie is contrived and forced. I can't see how any fan of Austen could come close to enjoying this mess!

If I could give more than 5 stars I would. This is (like Pride & Prejudice, 1995) one of the best Jane Austin films every made. Casting is superb. I can't see this movie without crying toward the end, and I've seen it at least a dozen times!. I have always loved Alan Rickman and in this film his acting is so nuanced and sensitive it makes me miss him even more, now that he's gone from us.
The scene near the end when Marianne is ill and he goes to get her mother---I defy you to find a more perfectly romantic moment. Upon returning with Mrs. Dashwood, he begins to leave the sick room and (finally, the little nit) Marianne looks up and thanks him. The transformation of his face, fleeting and so real, makes my heart ache.
The very end, the wedding scene, without a word spoken is so beautiful. Again, Alan Rickman's expression of joy is...well, simply wonderful. If you like period films you will love this.

I can and do watch this movie a thousand times. I laugh, cry and scowl in the same parts yet every viewing feels new. Body and soul is taken back into the lives of years gone by. Perfect casting, direction and scenery. My Favorite, Alan Rickman (RIP), steals my heart every time!

Nice movie good for an afternoon of just relaxation.  This is a simple movie about a family of two sisters and a mother, all women taking care of each other after the wealthy father/husband passes away.  By law his wealth went to the man of the family, who is the brother of her husband.  The brother took all the funds except a small monthly payment given to house the three women in a small cottage in the country side.  The two daughters fell in love with men who seem to not be available even though everyone is interested in everyone.  The men in love with the daughters have excuses as to why they love them, but ignore and avoid them.
Touching film. The acting was superb.

This is by far the best romantic movie i have seen! All along the story touches a very subtle line of love, the dialogues are exquisite and the story sails along so as to want you to desire a happy ending. Emma Thompson carries the whole movie extremely well. Her personification of Elinor makes you want to love her balance of mind, her broad range of tolerance and ultimately leaves you wishing that she ends up with the love of her life. A powerful romance, a bit of a colonial condescension and an immaculate portrayal of English life makes an unforgettable movie and one that I would recommend anyone to watch. (Pay attention to the English as well :) )

RELEASED IN 1995/96 and directed by Ang Lee, "Sense and Sensibility" chronicles events in England circa 1810 after Mr. Dashwood dies and legally leaves his estate to the son by his initial wife, which leaves his second wife and their three daughters relatively destitute. This negatively affects the marriageability of both practical Elinor (Emma Thompson) and romantic Marianne (Kate Winslet). When Elinor falls for the handsome Edward Ferrars (Hugh Grant) his kin object and put the kibosh on their blossoming relationship. Meanwhile, the noble but aging Colonel Brandon (Alan Rickman) becomes infatuated with young Marianne, but she is interested in the dashing John Willoughby (Greg Wise). Imogen Stubbs plays the rival for Edwards interest.

If you're in the mood for period piece drama/romance Sense and Sensibility fills the bill pretty well. It starts great, gets a tad tedious in the middle, but perks up at the end. The English locations/sets and costuming are superlative. You might want to take advantage of the subtitles to make out all the verbiage and keep track of all the names in the slightly convoluted relationship-oriented plot. In any case, its interesting seeing Winslet before her big success with Titanic (1997) and Rickman playing a straight role rather than hamming-it-up as a goofy villain.

THE MOVIE RUNS 136 minutes and was shot entirely in England (Devon, Norfolk, London, Wiltshire, Somerset and Cornwall, with studio work done in Shepperton). WRITERS: Jane Austen (novel) &  Emma Thompson (screenplay) .

GRADE: B

I've seen all adaptations of this film and this one over twenty times, being my favorite.  I think this to be one of Hugh Grant's best acting achievements.  His ability to get across how awkward he feels in the presence of strangers and how hard it is to even speak out feelings is impressive.  Hugh is a few months older than Emma in real life, and I found her strictness to manners and holding in personal feelings to be a perfect match for the role they both played.  Winslet was absolutely exceptional in playing a double role of first being a young, unsophisticated, unpolished woman to that of one who found her dignity, worth and maturity through Her mistakes and Col. Brandon. Alan Rickman, as Col. Brandon was great, as usual.  He died at only 69 yrs.  He is missed.  Having lived a life that served other's well but met with much hurt and usury he had begun to live a life expecting nothing from anyone; until Marianne.  He allowed her to see the goodness and promise that he held within himself to which both received the joy of love that was so important to each of them.  The mother, little sister, absolutely everyone was so well cast.

I bought this movie for my mom.  She loves it she always has, which makes me happy.  I personally think it's boring, but it's not really my type of movie honestly.  It does have one funny part in it, that makes me laugh, but I've just never really been able to stay awake until the end, no matter how hard I try.  I'm a fast thinker who likes fast movies though, so give me a soap opera or something like it and I'll fall straight to sleep!  I was happy to give this to my mom for Mother's Day though!  If this movie makes her happy, then it makes me happy!  Just a warning to all of you action lovers out there, this is a very slow movie about women who have nothing and chase after rich men.  It's boring to me, but there's a lot of people in my family who love it.  It's really a nice love story, and it has a lot of good characters and a couple of villains or something like it as well!  It has some wonderful acting in it too!  It's just not something that peaks my interest, but the rest of my family seems to like it!

I found myself cringing altogether too much last time I watched this version of S&S. Even the soundtrack (which is one of my favourite soundtracks of all time) couldn't save me from that reaction. Although it has its merits (beautiful sets, script and locations), and some of the casting is sublime (Alan Rickman, Robert Hardy, Harriet Walter, Imogen Stubbs and Greg Wise are all fantastically cast), there are definite problems with this adaptation. For one, Emma Thompson is just too old to play the part of Elinor convincingly. There, I said it. Some actors, though older than their character, are perfectly capable of selling me on their character's age. Thompson doesn't. She's a lovely actress and writer, just not in this film. I have reservations about Hugh Grant's portrayal of Edward as well. Whhhyyyyyy? What can they have been thinking letting Grant mince, bumble and stutter his way through a romantic hero's lines? Ugh. Edward was never this awkward and klutzy in the book. He's written as introverted and shy, not pathetic.

Someone else mentioned that the large age differences between actors and characters ruined this adaptation for them. Although I obviously agree to some extent, I think most of the actors made the best of it. I don't find, for example, the age gap between Alan Rickman and Kate Winslet distracting. Even Grant is believable as a man in his 20's.

All in all I much prefer the 2008 BBC version of Sense and Sensibility to this. They both have their problems, but at least I can watch that one without cringing.

I've seen several Jane Austen adaptions throughout the years, and this is by far one of my favorite! I re-watched it recently, and I must say, I appreciate all the extra trivia about this film that Amazon provides. Learning that Emma Thompson (the one and only!) not only acted in this film, but wrote the script, was such a rich piece of information that burrowed this movie even more deeply into my heart. The costumes and settings were beautiful, but the real treat was the musical score. The music danced around the characters, through the trees, and swallowed me in. For those who have seen and appreciated the music in the Kiera Knightly Pride & Prejudice version, this in on par (if not better!).

While I watched and rewatched this when I was younger, it has still been several years since I watched it the last time. I was surprised to find myself moving the couch closer to my tv in a weird attempt to see the actors/actresses' faces better. I think modern day movies (with modern-day big budgets) must have more frequent close-ups of actors'/actresses' faces, because I found myself wishing to see more of those wonderfully subtle, and oh-so-British, fleeting facial expressions. I suppose less camera angles was a budget issue, but even with that, this movie is a timeless classic and well worth anyone who loves a well-told Jane Austen story.

Sense And Sensibility was released in 1995. Luckily I saw this in the theatre. Emma Thompson stars in this fine adaptation of Jane Austen's novel. Fans of Jane Austen and Emma Thompson will like this the most.

My absolute favorite movie.  The eldest sister Eleanor Dashwood (Emma Thompson) is more conservative where as her younger sister Marianne (Kate Winslet) is one to not hide her feelings.  After the passing of their father, their half brother John Dashwood (James Fleet) and Fanny (Harriet Walter) come to take over the large estate left to the heir who is a son.  Fanny's brother Edward Ferrar's (Hugh Grant) stops to visit on his way back to London.  That's when Eleanor and Edward realize their attraction to one another, but Fanny who is very greedy and seems to want the Dashwood girls cast away from her and "good society, forces Edward to leave stating that his mother needs him."  I love the sisterly affection, and guidance by their mother for the girls to do right by one another.  The youngest daughter Margaret (Emilie Francois) plays a wonderful part as the shy youngest sister thrust into a sad world of losing her father, then their home.  Edward pulls her out of sadness, and starts a friendship with Margaret.  I love this movies for so many reasons, and it will remain my favorite always.  I hope others feel the same way.  Beautifully photographed, and an over all beautiful movie!

Holds up well 20 years later - Alan Rickman, sigh.  It has just the right blend of comedy and seriousness and does full justice to Austen's characters, plot and themes. A few characters are eliminated, (and of course the lovely and brilliant Emma Thompson was nowhere near 19 when she played Elinor) but overall it does a remarkable job at being faithful to the novel while still being a living, breathing alive movie.

It is painful to recall that the glorious baritone of Alan Rickman is now no longer with us -- but we do have his presence captured in this endearing interpretation of Jane Austen's "Sense and Sensibility."

Emma Thompson *carefully*  adapted her witty screenplay from Miss Austen's classic, and an ardent reader will be satisfied by abundant quotations taken directly from the text.  Thompson's additions do not detract from the beauty of this film, where everything from the wardrobe, settings and *Etiquette* of the Regency period is accurately depicted.  (E.g.: look at the comportment of the ladies when they receive visitors to their cottage.  Even the posing of the hands in their laps reflects authentic 18th century etiquette.)  All of these tiny details produce a film which is a joy to watch.

So please buy this film if you love top-notch acting, accurate costumes, settings, etiquette -- and if you believe, as I do, that Mr. Rickman's Colonel Brandon was one for the ages.

I just finished watching the 2008 BBC version it was a thousand times better than this version!! Horrible casting job by Emma Thompson! Emma Thompson, who was 36 at the time, cast herself as a 19 year old, Huge Grant, age 36, was cast as a 23 year old and Alan Rickman, 50, was cast as a 35 year old. In addition, Alan Rickman's love interest Kate Winslet had a 30 year age difference in real life. Imelda Staunton, age 56 in real life, giving birth to her first baby with Hugh Laurie in the movie??? You've got to be kidding me?? Hugh Grant also walked around like he'd broken his neck and had a neck collar on! I've been binge watching Jane Austen movies for the first time and I'm 55. Basically the actors don't match up with the age of the characters. It also felt rushed compared to the 2008 version and the intimate connections of the characters were skipped over.  I'm from the U.S. and I think BBC does Jane Austen books a service! To me, this is a watered down version of a wonderful novel! Do yourself a favor and get the 2008 series on Amazon. I promise you won't be disappointed!!!

I only enjoyed the acting, not the messages sent out or the ending. Elinor should have ended up with Brandon however, like many middle aged men, children were more desirable. I am very glad that we do no live in those times anymore. The movie failed to show Willoughby changing and becoming a better man. If he had done so, him and Marianne should have ended up together.

All the books from Austen's time period included encouraging huge age gaps within relationships and somehow making out that love was ever involved. Stockholm syndrome and indoctrination of young girls surely but never love. It was a very ageist society. Girls like Marianne were chosen because of their lack of experience and the fact that they were powerless! Especially if their class was lower and they did not have the wide range of choice that the upper classes had. Even then, parents gave their children off to whoever.

If this was ever going to be good, it should have defied society and matched same age couples together which is the right thing to do always. I'm very grateful for  science and other subjects which came along to give the majority of society common sense. The movie makers and Emma made a mistake by just playing into what the book said. Elinor and Brandon should have ended up together while Marianne and Willoughby grew as young people do and finally find real love.

This is one of my favorite movies. It is a huge favorite in my family as well.( My sister loves this movie so much, that two of the passages of dialogue and the song "Weep You No More Sad Fountains" where in her Wedding!!) I first saw this movie in the Theater; and have since purchased it on VHS, DVD, Blu-ray, and Digital. Ever current and future children in our family will know parts of this movie by heart; because we are constantly watching it.
Setting aside the stars that are in this film, Emma Thompson did an AMAZING job of bringing this Jane Austin Classic to life. The only true complaints I have are mainly factual inaccuracies. ( such as the scene when they are discussing where the Nile begins; and some of the clothing)
For me, this was a lovely film to watch, and keep watching. It is well acted and well cast. I Love Alan Rickman as Colonel Brandon. For me this was one of the first films where he Truly played a Good guy AMAZINGLY.(Though he is AWSOME as a Bad guy. ie: Sheriff Of Nottingham) My younger family members point out the Harry Potter actors all the time. This would be the first of many films that Emma Thompson and Alan Rickman would be in together.
Some of the best moments in this film where added in by Emma Thompson; and are not in the original book. Such as Brandon caring the ill Marianne.
The set designers, costumers, make-up artist, and all the crew did a wonderful job in bringing this film to life.
The song "Weep You No More Sad Fountains" is a favorite in our homes (Both the Kate Winslet version and others)
This movie as well as "Pride & Prejudice" (Colin Firth version, of course) are MUST see's for everyone.

Love the movie. Great to fall asleep to also. Watching the news before bed my wife and I recognized we kept going to sleep angry at the world. Perfect if you have tv sets with timers. Total game changer!

A reasonable mounting of this classic Jane Austen tale. This might've been superlative except for the script, which fails to cover some of the ground in the novel that was necessary to the successful execution of the story. The most egregious failure is in the conflict between Edward Farrars and his mother, who controls the family inheritance; it never gets enough traction to matter, even though that's essential to the resolution of his and Elinor's part of the drama. As for the casting, Kate Winslet was good as the willfully romantic Marianne, Emma Thompson did well enough with the somewhat ill-fitting Elinor, Alan Rickman was interesting as the frustrated Colonel Brandon, and Robert Hardy was spot on as the boisterous and expansive Sir John Middleton. The one outright misstep was Hugh Grant as Edward Farrars; he did his best to seem shy and retiring, but came off stiff and uncomfortable, as though he was surprised and unprepared to find himself stuffed into period costume and shoved in front of the camera.

Sense and Sensibility is my favorite Austen novel, but this is not the adaptation to watch if you want an ideal and romantic match to the book. Kate Winslet is excellent as Marianne as is Emilie Francois as Margaret. The best screen adaptation is the 2008 BBC TV mini-series...I could literally watch it over and over again.

Ang Lee outdid himself with this film.  Other than Emma Thompson being perhaps a little bid too old to truly play Elinor Dashwood (although she was excellent in the role, her acting skills cannot be denied), the film was beautifully done, the acting skillful, the story told with heart and finesse.  This novel by Jane Austen has often been slighted in favor of her better known "Pride and Prejudice," but it is just a fine a story and actually, more heart-wrenching, because it explores what happens to a family of women who are cast from a life of luxury into a life of "gentile poverty" and only have a roof over their heads (a rather shoddy roof at that) thanks to the beneficence of one of Mrs. Dashwood's cousins.  It is a true revelation of how cruel was society and the culture of early 19th century England.  The scene that got me when I initially saw this movie in a theatre, and it still does no matter how many times I've watched this film since then, is the scene where that takes place in the bedroom where Marianne lies deathly ill and Elinor is tending to her and begs the unconscious Marianne not to leave her alone.  Killer!

How Ang Lee could capture the atmosphere of 18th c. both visually and musically. Most versions have much more time to develop characters and can include more scenes from the book, but Emma Thompson is so skilled at jane Austen's writing that even her made-up dialogue strikes the ear as genuine.

The high point of Hugh Grant's career, Alan Rickman showing some serious vulnerability, Emma Thompson at her most stoic, and an early glimpse at Kate Winslet's range and depth...all supported by a brilliant ensemble. A scrumptious visual feast, with an equally evocative soundtrack.
I never get tired of Austen's Sense & Sensibility and Pride & Prejudice--book or good film adaptations, and this is one of the latter.  Emma Thompson, Hugh Grant, and Alan Rickman are great as well.

The actors perfectly depict the characters Jane Austen wrote of. Great casting! The director, screenwriter (love her!), and cast hit the nail on the head with regard to the ironies of the times. I especially loved the exchanges between John, the son, and Fannie, the daughter-in-law, convincing themselves that they did not really have to fulfill a dying man's wish. On top of that, the cinematography, the beautiful music, the costumes, and the locations chosen were all magnificent! I have seen this movie at least a dozen times, and will never tire of it. It remains one of my all time favorites!

Emma Thompson's screenplay won the Golden Globe and I think the Oscar too and deserved as much. Her gentlemen played so competently by Hugh Grant and Alan Rickman are of course far more attractive than the gents drawn by Austen but who cares! Well acted and beautifully realized on the screen it is not to be missed by anyone who enjoys period pieces.

My husband watched it to the end, pretended it was silly, but he secretly liked it. It might be a chick movie, but Emma Thompson's screenplay of an otherwise dull book is so good, that I was truly interested in every thing and every body's troubles. And I always get choked up at the end.

This Jane Austen tale is the story of two sisters, Elinor (Thompson) and Marianne (Winslet; how they fall in love, how they deal with it, and what they learn from it. The two sisters are vastly different people. Elinor is proper but not stuffy or stiff, quiet but not shy, and observant of the time's conventions. Emma Thompson did an amazing job inserting herself into the role. I'd previously seen the BBC version and was afraid that I wouldn't be able to overlook the age discrepancy of Thompson playing Elinor. I shouldn't have been fearful. Thompson's performance was flawless.

And then we have Marianne. Marianne is very passionate, artistic, and very wrapped up in her ideas of the way she thinks things should be. She can't see beyond her own judgements and doesn't understand people who are not like her. One one hand I liked that Marianne shirks conventions and what is expected of her to follow her heart. On the other hand I found her to be very immature and frustrating. Basically, Kate Winslet does a fantastic job of playing Marianne as a woman who hasn't yet had her ideas challenged or bumped up against the real world.

As is befitting one so dramatic, Marianne become wrapped up in a love triangle of sorts while Elinor's love is quiet and secret. The way these ladies go about being in love is like looking at opposite ends of a spectrum. Facial expressions and moments are captured beautifully and there is as much said in the quiet moments as in the moments when words are being spoken. That's what a film, a drama should be.

I highly recommend this adaptation and I wish I would have seen it sooner. As it is, I will be watching it again very soon.

This movie is so fabulous that there is no need to add more. So this is about the blu-ray, which, while not being demo quality, does justice to the beauty of the English countryside and the wonderful houses. I was concerned that it would not play in a Region 1 player but I took a chance with the listing A/B/C and I had no problem with it. I am thrilled to have it in blu at last.

I absolutely love all of the actors cast in this film, but they were terribly miscast for these roles. Elinor Dashwood was 19 years old. Marianne Dashwood was 16. When this film was made, Emma Thompson was 36 (!!) and Kate Winslet 20. Elinor and Marianne are sisters, not mother and daughter! While Emma is a fabulous woman and an amazing actress, this is almost as embarrassing as when her then-husband Kenneth Branagh played 19 year old Hamlet at 36. When a young man asks "To be or not to be..." that is part of growing up. When a man in his 30s asks the same question, that's just pathetic. But I digress... The film also strays too far from Austen's sublime text. Even the normally delightful Hugh Grant is in way over his head with this adaptation. What a grave disappointment this was.

Jane Austen provides us with an enchanting picture of what life would be like, if we did not have to work or struggle to make ends meet. Our servants satisfy that requirement of existence. We merely need to manage our financial affairs through adroitly structuring and arranging our romantic relationships. That said, there is much beauty, civility, and harmony in this portrayal of Victorian England British soldiers whose lives were not so idyllic no doubt made this abundance possible by keeping the colonies in line.  But no matter-- this elegant way of life, will perhaps be possible for all of us, once our robots are able enough.
Ang Lee (the director) impresses with the graceful and gentle flowing  of hope and yearning into sorrow  and confusion into redemption and fulfillment. The actors are superb. Select this film when you spirit need uplifting.

I would say that this is the essence of Sense and Sensibility, rather than an absolutely faithful reproduction of Jane Austen's work. Nevertheless, I enjoyed it very much. If the story was to be squeezed into a couple of hours, cuts would have to be made and a few non-essential characters were left out entirely, without harm to the plot. Presenting Sir John as a widower, thereby omitting his insipid wife and rambunctious young children, caused the screenwriter to take liberties with Jane Austen's original story, and some of the characters delivered lines that were actually spoken by other characters, but at least Jane Austen's words were used. In the book, Margaret Dashwood, the youngest of the three sisters, is barely mentioned but in this movie she is given a more prominent role with scenes that are obviously not from the pen of Jane Austen. However, her part was portrayed by such a pretty, charming and accomplished young actress that the alteration added to my enjoyment. The only part I wish was better acted was Elinor's crying breakdown. It was not an option, but I would have liked to have given this four and a half points because it was not perfect enough to earn five. If you like historical romances, this is well worth watching!

"Sense and Sensibility" is good adaptation of one of Jane Austen's most beloved novels. Jane Austen always found a way to create the most impossible situations imaginable to push her characters to the limit. This is the story of Marianne (Kate Winslet) and Elinor (Emma Thompson) and their unlucky situation in life. Due to their father dying they are virtually left homeless except for a small amount of money to live on each year. The story begins with a dramatic deathbed wish and you just know things are not going to work out for the best immediately. What surprised me was how funny this movie is when at times it is a near tragedy. Also the English countryside is so beautiful and there are a couple scenes in the amazing family library. Throughout this movie you will be on the edge of your seat wondering what could go wrong next. There are so many twists and turns in the story that it makes the movie absolutely fascinating. The men in this movie are also very interesting. They range from flaky to extremely chivalrous. Some of them also seem more swayed by money than love. Marianne and Elinor also must endure extreme emotional distress before they get what they want. But in the end you could not wish for a better conclusion.

~The Rebecca Review

I have watched both the BBC mini-series version and the movie. Although it pales in comparison to the  BBC Masterpiece version, as movie, it is one of the better big screen adaptations of Jane Austen's work.  Although Emma Thompson did a decent job with the screen play, i don't like the fact that she made a concerted effort to model  Edward Ferrars' personality around Hugh Grant's celebrity persona. Emma Thompson was 37 when this movie was released and she looks great, but she would have been better suited for the role of Mrs Dashwood. I don't understand why they made the decision to cast her as 19 year old Elinor, she just doesn't pull it off, and i found it distracting. If you are an Austin purist, and you haven't watched either version, my advice would be......start with the movie. If you watch Masterpiece first, you will have a difficult time enjoying the movie

Excellent cast, screen play, stellar direction, beautiful cinematography. Jane Austen's Sense and Sensibility is captured in a romantic, non-melodramatic way in this film. It's a 'must see' for all fans of period movies; but especially those who love Austen and her work.

On the subject of Harry Potter: If you are a fan, I highly encourage you to see this, even if the genre usually isn't your bag. It's worth it to see Professor Trelawney (Emma Thompson) as the daughter of Madam Pomfrey (Gemma Jones); the original Fat Lady (the late, great Elizabeth Spriggs), who gossips with Cornelius Fudge (Robert Hardy) and is the mother of Dolores Umbridge (Imelda Staunton...who is surprisingly likeable here as a funny, shallow, vapid woman of the time); and, of course, the aforementioned Professor Snape (the honey-voiced, unrivaled Alan Rickman).

For House fans: Hugh Laurie is well cast as the long-suffering and acidly humorous Mr. Palmer, husband of Imelda Staunton's Charlotte Jennings Palmer. Bonus: He gets to use his real accent!

This is a bit of perfection all around...give it a try and you won't be sorry!

Marianne was romantic still but not quite as outspoken and petulant as earlier versions presented her except when it came to Willoughby. Although this movie is not absolutely true to the book, the changes made are wonderful and add greatly to the enjoyment of the movie. I believe that Ms Thompson caught the emotion of the story very well and enhanced it with both her writing of the script and her acting in it. Her character is the driving force of the story and her portrayal is perfect. I know she was a bit old for the role but she looked lovely and fit the role perfectly. She can say more with silence than any actress I've ever seen. This is a wonderful cast with every single person "spot on" in their performance. It is beautifully filmed. I've looked at it many times and it makes every other production of this book just seem boring. I was a little perplexed by the way  Hugh Grant seemed to creep around on his toes sort of bent forward in most scenes but I assume that is what he was directed to do. He certainly made a charming and believable Eward Ferrars and that is what is important. I thought Alan Rickman was wonderful as Col. Brandon and I've never seen Marianne portrayed better than Kate Winslet did it. She gave it just the correct touch of young love out of control and unable to help her behavior. The difference in the way she took heartbreak and the way her sister handled her own was, thankfully, brought out in one of the last scenes when Marianne compares her behavior to her sisters. Just a beautifully done film.

I've seen Jane Austen's 1970's production of Sense And Sensibility and enjoyed it. But this movie truly promotes the book on which it's based. The performances and the setting are outstanding.

I commend Emma Thompson for how she wrote the screenplay. The humor is so delicate as it inspires laughter. Although it's not a tear-jerker for me, it very well may be for somebody else. The book's plot is so well-carried out in the movie that it uncovers the hearts of many women, who have found themselves searching for love in the modest and bashful manner which we were taught long before the boldness of this generation erupted.

Mrs. Jennings is the funniest character in the movie. While she is as non-scandalous as the proper society required especially women to be in their time, she borders on "non-scandalous". She loves gossip, and as thirteen year-old Margaret points out, "She talks about things." I think almost every main character, except for snobbish Fanny and her spineless husband, is evaluated by Mrs. Jennings, who is not shy about expressing her thoughts. Loveable character.

Another favorite of mine is Colonel Brandon. He is an ideal man (yet in disguise by a very humble nature) for any woman with a craving for true romance in her life, like Marianne.

I never would have read the book before seeing the movie. But now... I recommend them both (and the previous movie version if available now).

This book is obviously a classic and this adaptation was done so well that I literally watch it all of the time. I felt that this movie captured the essence of the characters superbly well, which can be hard to do with such a classic and well loved story.

I adore British movies... are so witty and sooooooo romantic!  The acting is superb in "Sense & Sensibility" and I appreciate that I can UNDERSTAND what they're saying through their British accents (I always use the available subtitles).  I would recommend this movie to EVERYONE... especially the ladies.  You will NOT be disappointed!  This is one of my all-time favorite movies!  Oh, and the costumes and sets are extraordinarily beautiful!

Additionally, I can't open the BBC version no matter how many times I try, therefore, I am forced to watch this when I want to "read" (okay watch) a J. Austen film.

A must see for anyone... a stupendously amazing cast will have you fall in love with this movie!

I think that Emma Thompson's age was perfect for Elinor in terms of what the movie  is conveying about English society at the time. Both daughters are forced by their circumstances to be neurotically desparate to find husbands, and their wretchedness is emphasized by the slightly "too" old Elinor. Whether the character was that old in the book, I don't care. That detail works perfectly in this screen version.

Another interesting fact is that all the men in the movie seem to be victims of the crazy world they've created. The Hugh Grant character tiptoes around like he's about to topple over at any moment. The colonel is in his own kind of daze. The married men are miserable or driven to looniness or mean-spiritedness. The only free spirit is the younger sister's early suitor, but of course he's punished by both his society and his conscience for his behavior.

I am reviewing the movie because of the way it makes me feel - lower blood pressure, faith that all will come out right in the end, respite from the travails of my world, etc.  This is a wonderful presentation of one of my favorite Jane Austen books with all of the players in exactly the right, believable roles.  I am not an expert on the period but Thompson makes me believe she and her production staff are.  For an Anglophile, the beautiful English countryside is as much a character as the players. Emma Thompson, one of my favorite artists and in my opinion, beautiful, was too old to play this part.  Because of her acting skill, the movie was not ruined for me by that, but I kept noticing it.  Ms. Thompson, though not at all old, projects maturity, and Gemma Jones projects younger than she was when this film was made, so even though I hadn't read the book, I kept thinking that Mrs. Dashwood must have birthed Elinor as a teenager.  That was okay for me, but Elinor always seemed 30 in this version of the story, and I kept thinking she would have been considered a spinster by that age and so I didn't understand why her dying father spoke of a dowry for her.  In appearance, a 30 year old Elinor would have long ago had a season, and obviously not married.  She seemed in appearance and behavior, more an aunt to Marianne, and a younger sister to Mrs. Dashwood, though in the story she was sister and daughter.  Anyway, despite the miscasting, I still liked this film, it has many of the actresses/actors I love in it, and everyone did a good job.  I'm happy Ms. Thompson took the part, but it would be nice to see a remake of this screenplay with age appropriate actors - it would likely be even a better movie, provided the actresses/actors are as fine as those in this production.  I've watched it many times and I think my favorite character is Lucy, because she comes from a disadvantaged background and time for women, and just by using her wits, manages to marry well, which in her time was like winning the lottery.  She was the most proactive female character, and I like women action characters, though I usually don't like gold diggers, Lucy has so few options in the 19th century for meaningful work, that marrying well was one of the few respectable options she had for a decent life for herself.  With very few protectors, no great beauty and no education, she married well.  I was pleased the Dashwood girls married well too.  I know I was supposed to feel more deeply for the Dashwood family as they had a reversal of fortune with the death of their beloved husband/father, but even in their financial straits of only 500 pounds a year, they lived in a two story house with two servants, and ate well with their rich relatives as often as they chose.  So they suffered a reversal, but they weren't homeless or without income.  I know the filmmakers tried to show a real fall into poverty, but though they suffered a loss of a beloved family member, whom they never mentioned after they left their family home, it's hard to think of people with two servants as poor, though they were undoubtedly poorer.  Mostly Elinor seemed slightly overly bossy towards Marianne (as if in anticipation of Marianne's disappointment - something I dislike in film, when a character forecasts something too early in the story), and Kate Winslet, though young, seemed older than a super naive 16 year Marianne.  Willouby was not all that impressive to me either - as Marianne's first boyfriend; I think his part should have been written with the care that Edward's part was written - it was clear why Elinor liked Edward; it would have been good to show the reasons Marianne adored Willouby.  I think Willouby carrying Marianne home after she sprained her ankle was to be proof of something, but it was not enough, I needed more Willouby time, more things he actually did that showed why he was so appealing.  After all, Emma Thompson did not just rely on Hugh Grants good looks to show why she was fond of Edward, she showed in the story why Edward's character was so appealing.  With an Elinor too bossy for little reason, and Marianne crushed by a Willouby who was underwritten, it was hard to attach completely to the story, but I attached partially enough to enjoy it, mostly due to the well written Elinor/Edward romance, and the fine acting by all. I'd give it a three and a half stars.

This particular edition of Sense & Sensibility is my favorite because it stays faithful to Jane Austen's book. Ema Thompson does an exceptional job portraying the older sister, Elinor. Kate Winslet does a fine job as Marianne, the romantic younger sister. The story cleverly illustrates the manners, mores and morals of  society at the time, as well as the disadvantages of being a female. The story is built around the tragic death of the girl's father and the family fortunes being "entailed" to the eldest son of his previous marriage. The two girls and their mother have to give up their home and are economically at the mercy of a half-brother who barely knows them and the brother's greedy wife, who has no sympathy for the girls, their mother.or the situation.  The romantic adventures of both girls keep you entertained. I loved the "happily ever after" ending.

The Dashwood sisters (Emma Thompson, Kate Winslett, Emilie Francois) and their mother (Gemma Jones) are left in a precarious position when Mr. Dashwood (Tom Wilkinson) dies and the bulk of his estate goes to his son from a previous marriage (James Fleet), who allows them a very small stipend on which to live.  In a society where women are denied autonomy, they must rely on the kindness of in-laws and pray for advantageous marriages.  Nevertheless, Elinor and Marianne hold on to the hope that they will marry for love and not merely economic gain.

This engaging and moving film, brilliantly acted, functions for much of its length as a scathing indictment of a time when the circumstances of talented and intelligent women were almost entirely dependent on the men in their lives.  However, it becomes complicit in this unfortunate social institution (spoiler ahead) with its ending, in which the sisters achieve happiness by marrying the right men.  Nevertheless, I had become so invested in the characters that I wanted them to have their happy ending and didn't much mind that the form it took actually undercut a major theme of the film.

Just a heads up for those who, like me, are getting impatient for a Blu-ray release in the United States (c'mon, Sony, this was the Golden Globe Best Pic winner!): I took a shot at ordering the import, stuck it into my Magnavox Wal Mart Cheapie blu-ray player and whaddya know, it works.

The picture quality for this blu-ray is stunning in places, and not-so-stunning in other places (a bit soft here and there).  But every second of it is gorgeous compared with the DVD release, which was bad even by SD standards.  But hang on to the DVD for Emma Thompson's witty commentary, because it's not on the blu-ray.

This is one of my five favorite films, and I was psyched outta my head to see it look so sharp, so I may not be a level-headed reviewer, but in the parts (about 80% of the run time) where the picture quality is very good, I thought I was looking at one of the best looking movies I'd ever seen.  I saw little facial gestures and nuanced physical acting I hadn't noticed in my umpteen previous viewings on DVD.  The colors of the country-side, the outfits, the foods, the horses, and the decor of the homes, taken altogether in the rhythm and tone that Ang Lee presents here, is a real marvel.  Seeing (and hearing) it on blu-ray, I was swept back to 1995 when I was knocked out by it at the movie theater.  This is an underrated masterpiece in my opinion.  Best chick flick of all time.

I first saw this film under bizarre circumstances. Friends invited me to their place following a personal tragedy, and as a way to distract me, they played this movie for me on their big-screen DVD player. It did in fact manage to distract me, especially recognizing Snape (Alan Rickman) in the person of Colonel Brandon. Hey, he's a nice guy in this picture!

There are no villains, really. There are only people, such as Willoughby, who are pressed by circumstances into being cruel to those who love them. Everyone is very, very civilized, actually, the way only the British can be.

No, I take that back: Elinor and Marianne Dashwood, the beautiful Emma Thompson and Kate Winslet respectively, have a sister-in-law who is truly evil. But then, she dresses the part, and sounds the part: you can't miss her.

Here's a curious fact: Emma Thompson got a Golden Globe AND an academy award, but not for her acting. She also wrote the screenplay. The DVD includes her speech upon acceptance of the Golden Globe, and it is a classic. In it, she acknowledges that they owe it all to Jane Austen, and then asks what Miss Austen would say if she were there. She then read her (Jane Austen's) speech, and it was perfect! It sounded just like her, and was amusing with the dry wit that makes her books so delightful.

Anyway, I have no hesitation in giving Sense & Sensibility a full five stars. It is a beautiful movie in all respects. I am especially crazy about the costumes.

The 2008 BBC version goes into more detail and I like it more. But this is still a good version too. The Movie it's self has NO CONs What-so-ever and has wonderful music in it. I highly recomend it to anyone looking for a clean movie to watch!

This movie was my first taste of Jane Austen.  I have to admit, when it first came out I was a kid, so I wrote it off as boring and didn't bother to watch.  In my teens I realized that I actually liked period drama's, and this movie quickly became a favorite of mine!

 The movie itself, as a period drama is first class!  Although it isn't completely faithful to the book, it is my favorite of the adaptations I've seen ('07, and '81).  The casting is superb (although 2 of the actors were a bit older than their book counterparts); and their acting leaps & bounds better than the '81!  The scenery, and stately homes are stunning!!  Also, the soundtrack fits the period, and compliments the storyline very well.

 Most likely, if the viewer hasn't read the book, the alterations, and missing characters shouldn't affect their opinion much.
_______

**SPOILER ALERT**

As for the (most notable) missing scenes/parts:

  - Willoughby's visit, and conversation with Elinor at Cleveland (during Marianne's sickness).  The movie tried to rectify it by way of Col. Brandon.  After his revealing Willoughby's seduction of his ward to Elinor, he proceeds to tell her he inquired, and has reason to believe that Willoughby's intentions were not entirely as dishonorable toward Marianne.
..It's not quite as satisfying as hearing it come from Willoughby himself though.

  - Edward's week stay, not long after they arrived (on his way back from visiting Lucy in Plymouth).  The book scene conveyed the troubled mind of Edward, and his internal conflicting feelings as regards Elinor, and Lucy.
And provided a hint of what was to come, with the lock of hair seen by all in his ring (which he passed off as Fanny's, and the Dashwood sisters supposed he somehow obtained a lock of Elinor's without her knowing).

- The dinner party with Mrs. Ferrars & Jennings, the Dashwood's, Steels', and Middleton's.  Not a major loss there, being that Fanny made it clear at the beginning that their mother expected Edward to marry a woman of means and fortune, otherwise suffer being disinherited.
  And before revealing her engagement, Lucy told Elinor she finally met Mrs. Ferrars (after being invited to stay with the J. Dashwood's in London).
______

  The missing characters:

  I personally don't mind the fact that Lady Middleton (& children) were left out (the movie stated Sir John was a widower).

In the book, Miss Austen describes her as "(though perfectly well bred,) she was reserved, cold, and had nothing to say for herself beyond the most common-place enquiry or remark".
 With that said, it wasn't that much of a loss to leave her out being that she and Mrs. (John) Dashwood were so much alike ("there was a kind of cold hearted selfishness on both sides, which mutually attracted them; and they sympathized with each other in an insipid propriety of demeanour, and a general want of understanding").
In the book, all she really did was dote on her children, and play hostess.

  They also left out the other Miss Steel, which wasn't a big deal either.  The movie showed Lucy spilling her secret to Fanny instead.

Along with the famous Andrew Davies BBC/A&E miniseries of PRIDE AND PREJUDICE, SENSE AND SENSIBILITY was the first of the famous series of adaptations in the mid 90s that sparked a kind of cultural Jane Austen boom. It was also considered at the time one of the best, although its pretty-pretty costumes, sets and cinematography were soon supplemented in the imagination(almost blessedly) by the terrifically gritty and muddy BBC version of PERSUASION helmed by Roger Mitchell. Even so, the exquisite prettiness of this Ang Lee-directed version presents one vision of Jane Austen very dear to many readers' hearts, and the deservedly Oscar-winning screenplay by Emma Thompson brings out much of the novel's great humor as well as its poignancy, and makes the plot's many twists and turns compelling.

Many Austen scholars at the time noted that Thompson (then thirty-six) was too old to be quite believable at the elder and more stoic of the Dashwood sisters, Elinor; but the difference in marriageability ages in the late 20th century seems to account better now for the disparity in Thompson's age and that of her heroine. Similarly, though Hugh Grant was faulted in 1995 for pulling a more pronounced version of his usual adorably bashful stammering shtick as Elinor's admirer, Edward Ferrars, in retrospect it seems quite approrpiate to the character (and helps explain why he has such difficulty making his love for Elinor known in his earlier scenes). What has not improved over time is the odd casting of Alan Rickman as the more faithful of Marianne's beaux, Colonel Brandon: his sinister and slow delivery (used to such beautiful effect in other films) seems oddly out of whack, such that by the end it seems almost as if the Dashwoods are marrying poor Marianne off to a second Bluebeard. Much more successful are the impossibly dashing Greg Wise (Thompson's romantic partner after this film) as Willoughby, the estimable Harriet Walter as Mrs. John Dashwood, Hugh Laurie as an amusingly sour Mr. Palmer, and Elizabeth Spriggs as the impossibly vivacious Mrs. Jennings. The highest performing honors belong to Emma Thompson, ideally cast as the patient Elinor, and Kate Winslet as her emotional sister Marianne: it is a testament to both women's skills that, though they had played very similar roles recently before this film that had made enormous impacts (Thompson as the sisterly and wise Margaret Schlegel in HOWARDS END, and Winslet as the overwrought teenager Juliet Hulme in HEAVENLY CREATURES), their performances in this film are quite distinct from those earlier successes.

This had been on my "to watch" list for about ten years. I'm slow, I know. But I'm glad I finally got to it, because it was really a lovely movie. I was drawn in from the first minute and so impressed with the acting talent. It's difficult to make an impact as an actor and still be understated, and yet everyone in this film seemed to pull it off effortlessly. Excellent screen adaption, and worth seeing.
This is a good production of the old story.  Good actors and nice costuming and setting.  Good viewing for a wet Sunday afternoon!
I like this version! I was tickled to see the awards ceremony speech Emma Thompson gave included in bonus features. Enjoyed the costumes and locations. Brilliant work!
The BEST version of Jane Austen's novel,but I happen to love Emma Thompson and Hugh Grant. The love and care between the sisters is beautifully done.

The Emma Thompson version is not so good = so many details/characters left out.
 Col Brandon is awful. Edward & Charlotte, also.
 I finished the book then watched the movie.
If a viewer didn't know the story I would think they'd have questions.
Ema Thompson and the rest of the lead actors were excellent and it was a well-told story, sticking to the book as much as a movie can.  There was a lot of heart in this movie and good acting by all.
One of my favorite movies!! When I'm feeling a little love sick I watch this movie and i feel better!! It has many famous actors and i really love the interactions between the characters.

It is ridiculous to read the billing that this movie "STARS"  Tom Wilkinson and James Fleet and that the "SUPPORTING ACTORS"  are all the others!  Tom Wilkinson and James Fleet are seen very briefly at the beginning of the movie and the "SUPPORTING ACTORS" are the leads that carry the story through to it's conclusion.

The generation of Asian directors erupted in the West since the mid-eighties with unusual force. Japan lost its customary leadership and Ang Lee was part of that breed of talented directors of the rising sun.

In my view, Lee has done many good movies but if it comes to masterpieces, there are two that are far above the rest: Lust caution and Sense and Sensibility.

Armed with this visual refinement that goes back to James Ivory (What Remains the day) and rate of rhythmic cadences, Ang Lee undertakes the Herculean task of bringing to the screen so English a work like this.

And the end result was sublime. The repertoire is perfect, the scenery is simply mesmerizing, the accurate and incisive dialogues. Thus, Lee takes advantage of laying bare the background of social conventions so characteristic of the time and puritanical double standard that nested in every corner of the households is in Devonshire and London.

Two sisters, impoverished after the death of his father in the flesh feel the stares, gossip and the scorn of a wealthy class in England in the nineteenth century.

The performances of Emma Thompson, Tom Wilkinson, Alan Rickman and Hugh Grant added an extra touch to this superb production, I do not hesitate to include it within twenty great cinematic achievements of the decade of the nineties.
I ordered this and got it three days later, simply amazing. If only others would be so expeditious! Thanks guys/gals! *Mary*
Clear, light, balanced, easy to watch, and so beautifully made that there is always fresh pleasure seeing it again.  It may even be better (as a movie) than the book is (as a book).

Having gotten very interested in Jane Austen lately, I watched this movie once again last week. I have owned it on VHS for about 13 years. It is, and always will be one of my favorite movies of all time. It has beautiful outdoor scenes, beautiful dialogue and superb acting. Time to get the DVD!
Love Sense and Sensability. It would be so nice if people were required to be courteous and well mannered as they are in this movie.

This movie is great for depicting what true love is (and is not). The actors are all fantastically suited for their chosen roles. This is a movie one wants to watch over and over. I can't say enough good about this movie. It's among my top ten favorites of all time! We need many more movies like this!

This is a near-perfect film adaptation of one of Jane Austen's classic novels; my only criticism is that Emma Thompson is rather old to be portraying a 19-year-old girl.  Despite that, she does an incredible job with the part, as do all the actors in this movie.  Alan Rickman's Colonel Brandon makes me swoon every time I watch it.  The direction is lovely - every scene is like a painting, with beautiful landscapes, set design, and costumes.  I had to buy a second copy on Blu-Ray because I wore out my original DVD.

I love this movie. Unlike the romance Hollywood of today tries to get you to buy into, this is fresh and full of hope and love even after a seeming loss. And no one needs to get naked or suffer from potty-mouth! A timeless classic our writers of today need to use as an example. You can keep it clean, people, and still tell a great story!

I have a great appreciation for English literature and English drama.  Sense & Sensibility and Pride & Prejudice with the excellent casts have been well done.  Emma Thompson? No one does it better.  The dvd is in excellent condition and I was very happy to have found this version on Amazon. I am a faithful shopper now!

Hugh Grant is wonderfully charismatic, a master of self-deprecating humor, yet clearly able to show depth in a dramatic role. Being on a Hugh Grant kick lately I watched three of his films all in the same week. Love Actually, Sense & Sensibility, and 4 Weddings and a Funeral. Fun way to watch these movies because of the overlap in players and to understand classic British style: themes include tension between being proper and true to oneself, a wide cast of characters all intertwined, somehow, uncertainty of who will end up with who, extreme, offbeat secondary characters that are almost caricatures, and everything wrapped up neatly in the last 5-10 minutes of the film. Another commonality seems to be a randomness of billings, in this one Grant was given a top billing and a picture on the DVD cover, but was very much a secondary character. More talked about than actually shown. In his scenes he was so constrained/proper that it was almost painful to watch. Great acting and wonderfully unpredictable as far as who will end up with who.

As far as following the story, I think this adaptation did a decent job following the book.  There were a few changes that I couldn't figure out why they did them, but they were minor. (why change Edward's engagement to Lucy from 4 to 5 years?  Does it matter?)  That said, everyone was too old for the characters that they were playing.  Also, with the exception of Alan Rickman, the acting was stilted and forced.  I never was convinced I was watching a story unfold before my eyes.  I was definitely watching a fictional movie.  Alan Rickman's performance as Col. Brandon redeemed this movie from 2 to 3 stars.

This movie was from the beginnng an attention getter.  I have watched it many times on A&E.  It flows so well, and I never lose interest in it.  It takes you to a place where Gentlemen were Gentlemen, and Ladies were Ladies.
The romantic overtones were supurb.  Not a lot of sexual overtones, just a great romantic movie.

I know this one is closer to the book, but I still like the other movie version better. I like the actors that played the characters better and the story, while not perfectly true to the book, was wonderful. I was disappointed with Hugh Grant as Frederick. He was too simpering for my taste. Looked stiff in his cravat.

Despite the fact that much of Austen's language from "Sense and Sensibility" is not included in this film, the spirit and soul of her characters and plot remain. Since this was Austen's first attempt at writing, much of her language is stilted to the modern ear and Ms. Thompson's rewrite for the screenplay makes it flow in a more sensible fashion. It's filmed in loving detail by Ang Lee, saturated in light, Kate Winslet's Marianne and Emma Thompson's Elinor shine in their roles as siblings and the complications that arise from that relationship. A "new" sister, Margaret, is added to explain the culture of the period as she blurts out questions that the modern audience may be thinking to have the family answer.

Imelda Staunton and Hugh Laurie as the Palmers are a wonderful foil to the rather silly manners of the day and Greg Wise provides a delicious villian as the rogue Willoughby. Hugh Grant as love interest Edward is underplayed; this role was cast before his big splash in "Notting Hill." And Alan Rickman as Marianne's suitor was just lovely.

Yes, this is chick flick-no explosions, no one killed, no blood. Just a story about human relationships, overcoming adversity, and a bit of romance.
This movie is an old favorite of mine. I am glad to get it on DVD. I look forward to sharing it with my girls when they get a little older. There are some good lessons in it.

This has got to be one of my all time fav movies and I watch it several times throughout the year.  Love the classic period pieces and anything Jane Austen is fantastic in my book.  Definitely recommend!!!

I found myself in the mood for both a classic "chick flick" and a visual introduction to the novels of Jane Austen; so I rented this movie to watch with my fiancee. She enjoyed it, but I think I liked it a lot more. I'm old enough now that I can enjoy movies like this, but I certainly would not have appreciated or enjoyed it 10 years ago when still in my late teens. If you are a man looking for a reason to watch this movie, here's one. It stars 3 people who later became Harry Potter professors: Emma Thompson (amazing actress who played Professor Trelawny and also co-starred with Will Ferrell in Stranger Than Fiction), Alan Rickman (Professor Snape who is famous for playing villains in Die Hard and Quigley Down Under - it is weird seeing him in this unusal good guy role), and the woman who plays Professor Delores Umbridge, whom we all love to hate in the Harry Potter movies. Also there is a small role for Dr House before he was House, M.D.: Season One, cranky even then because his character was married to Delores Umbridge! And in case you are worried about watching this movie because you hate Hugh Grant from his typical clean-cut British loverboy roles like Nine Months, don't worry about it. He still plays a clean-cut British loverboy in this movie, but he is actually sort of likeable here. It also stars Kate Winslet from Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (Widescreen Edition). I am not going to get into the plot of this movie because you can find that anywhere. Suffice it to say that I enjoyed this movie so much that now I want to read Jane Austen's books.

This has to be the best video version of the Jane Austen classic.  Emma Tompkins' hand was in all aspects of the production, especially the screenplay, which she wrote herself.  It shows. Excellent characterizations, casting, with extremely high production values worthy and reminiscent of the BBC PBS Masterpiece Theatre production.  One can almost visualize Alistair Cooke in an English library setting, seated in a leather wing chair with book in hand, ready to introduce the movie.  At any rate, only one word: superb.  Added bonus of Hugh (pre-House) Laurie as the hysterically funny Mr. Palmer, with pained and bored expressions and small utterances under his breath as his nitwit wife jabbers away. Priceless.

Anyone who loves Jane Austen should love this movie.  It's definitely a woman's movie, most men not caring for the affectations of the 1800s "genteel" class.  Lots of romance, heartbreak, and gorgeous scenery.  Second only to "Pride and Prejudice."  Highly recommended.

The DVD for Jane Austin's Sense and Sensibility is excellent.
The DVD is as described. It was mailed quickly. I recommend this seller.

Although the Pride and prejudice tv series with Colin Firth and Jenifer Ehle impressed me, I have to admit that my favorite adaptation of a Jane Austen novel remains Emma Thompson's and Ang Lee's Sense and Sensibility.

This movie is an adaptation of Jane Austen's first novel in which three sisters, named Elinor, Marianne, Margaret, and their mother have to move out of their home and relocate in a small cottage, due to the death of their father whose house has become the property of their brother-in-law and of his avaricious wife. At the same time, Elinor and Marianne both fall in love with gentlemen, played by Alan Rickman, Hugh Grant and Greg Wise, (who became in real life the husband of Emma Thompson herself) and whose lives are not what they seem to be.

As I don't want to reveal too much of the plot, I just want to say that what really impressed me was how Ang Lee managed to keep his direction very simple. There are no useless close-ups, no overbearing music and no over acting with his actors. Instead, he just lets them interpret their roles in the most subtlest way. And, unlike certain Jane Austen adaptations, Ang Lee doesn't use flashbacks to explain incidents that occur in the past or to enrich the character's dialogues. Instead, he just lets the actors speak and explain what happened. Finally, Ang Lee's shots look just like asian paintings and add details that were not included in the novel, but enhance the context of the british society in Jane Austen's novel, such as the grand ball which instead of occurring in a big room, happens through different rooms, each divided by a certain social status.

As for Emma Thompson's very funny script, she manages to condense the novel's plot in two hours, with such efficiency that she doesn't lose any of the important elements of the story. Not only that, she also gives room to certain characters like Margaret, and even enriches the story with scenes that never occurred in the book, like the discussion between Elinor and Edward in the library as they manage to get Margaret out of her hiding spot. The scene is so funny and believable in its dialogue that you really think that it was in the book, which was something that a professor, or a viewer I'm not too sure, told Emma Thompson and her producer, something they both revealed in the commentaries on the DVD.

Speaking of special features, I loved the details and information that Emma Thompson and her producer gave in their commentaries, some of which were also noted in the production diaries of the movie. You get to learn more about the movie 's production and also on her work as screenwriter and all the modifications she had to do to transpose the novel into a movie.

Finally, there is, in the special features, an excerpt from the Golden Globes ceremony in 1996, during which Emma Thompson received a prize and did a great speech, imagining what Jane Austen would have said if she had been at that ceremony.

In the end, I don't think the movie would have been as successful and as funny if Emma Thopmson and Ang Lee had not been working on this movie, which really deserved its Oscar for best scriptwriting, Golden Globe, and golden bear at the Berlin film festival.

Don't get this version.  Get the 2008 BBC version.  This version was poorly cast and lacked chemistry.  Except for Alan Rickman who was actually pretty great as Colonel Brandon.  The rest though, not so much.  Especially Emma Thompson and Hugh Grant who had zero chemistry as Elinor and Edward.  Emma Thompson was actually pretty bland.  The 2008 BBC version has everything this one lacked.
The movie is light, has intrigue, has personal conflict that you relate to and is a "happy" movie.  Watching you takes you out of life into a fun, smiling time.

This particular movie is one I have watched over and over. I don't ever get tired of this version. I have seen others and they didn't have the cast that made this edition so wonderful. It's a movie for years of entertainment and just joyful to watch. It's funny, poignant, sad and best of all, happy endings!!!!

Films don't get any better than this.  First, there is the vibrant screenplay of Emma Thompson that captures the essence of Jane Austen's wonderful novel.  Then, there is the extraordinarily talented cast of Emma Thompson as Elinor Dashwood, Kate Winslet as Marianne Dashwood, Gemma Jones as Mrs. Dashwood, Alan Rickman as Colonel Brandon, Hugh Grant as Edward Ferrars, and Harriet Walter as Fanny Ferrars Dashwood and many others, led by the cinematically inspired direction of Ang Lee.  This film has everything to like.  A wonderful viewing experience that can be repeated as many times as you wish.

This, as another review has remarked, is a serviceable translation of Austen's novel to the screen.

It has, on the whole, a wonderful cast doing a pretty good job, and great production values. Though Hugh Grant seems uncomfortable as Elinor's beloved,  I do love the other Hugh, Hugh Laurie, who rather touchingly reveals something that the novel only suggests:  Mr. Palmer gradually falls more than half in love with Elinor.  (The contrast between Elinor and Mrs. Palmer is painful.)  Emma Thompson's Elinor may be a little older than we might have imagine her, but she beautifully conveys Elinor's isolation and stress--she is so often the only  person of sense in the room.  My biggest complaint is that the scene between Elinor and her sister Marianne's faithless lover Willoughby is pretty weak--Elinor is even closer to forgiving that scoundrel here than she is in the novel.  Miss Austen was far too easy on him, and the film is worse.

Really, it's not perfect, but it's a very engaging film--you'll enjoy it.
whats not to love about jane austen's tale of love. This is a wonderful adaptation by Emma Thompson. She did a wonderful job making it appealing for this generation.

I watched this film 4 times already and I still find it very agreeable. It's really funny and very well done. First time i watched it, for some reason Emma thompson and Kate winslet looked the same to me and I didn't know who was Elinor or Marianne either. Clearly I must have drank to much beer at the time. I am somewhat like Marianne and i've had the most unfortunate experience with an "Elinor" of my own who was an absolute complete waste of my time, but i digress.

They both meet guys and go through trivial experiences and balance each other out along the way.

The older sister was FAR to old looking to be beleivable(I really thought she was the mother figure in the opening scenes)and her love intrest was poorly casted as to young to be even intrested in her.
